content: Interesting problem, the non closed test cases did take me by surprise though.

I would either remove weird cases (like this one
|-
|-
) or add extra requirement to detect non closed shapes. Except that, nice and easy problem

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Test cases could be more original, either that it's a good work that can be use for shortest or fastest code.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's straight forward and easy for a clash. Solved in ~2 minutes. Could be interesting for shortest mode.

Interesting contribution.
However I'm failing to understand the statement properly.
Especially when it comes to this case:
|-
|-
How are we supposed to interpret this "shape"?
Where are the boundaries? It looks open on the right side.
I am not seeing how it makes sense to compute the "perimeter" of an open shape like that.
Similarly, imagine you have a "shape" like this one (which satisfies the constraints of the puzzle)
2
|
|
Your code outputs 6, but how is that possible?
I mean we have two segments which essentially form a segment of length 6, yes, but with 0 width, how can you compute the perimeter of a single segment?

I think I must have misunderstood the statement entirely.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I like the idea and overall feel of the puzzle but it needs reworking.
It should be a WIP, not Ready.

> Keep in mind that there are no spaces after the last character and the first character is not a space.
You need to add that that works vertically too.
I'm talking about that there can't be any shapes like
/--\ /--\
|   -   |
\------/

I like it, but the "|-" test cases are kind of lazy and pretty hard to think of as "shapes" with a sensible perimeter. My solution worked first time just by following the problem statement, so it's perfectly doable, but it'd be nice if more of the cases were as creative as the last two. It's just a suggestion, though; I think the problem is acceptable as-is, modulo that it probably shouldn't be eligible for reverse mode.
I don't exactly understand what you mean by that, since the code will work for that too.

It will not work correctly
There is an ' ' in the first line of my shape. The perimeter from first line goes to the second line goes back at the middle of a first part. It's a horseshoe shape.
Cases like that is allowed by the rules but are not covered by tests/your code.

In addition:
> The triangle is [[lines]] lines
What is triangle that this line is refferencing to?
Also,  "[[lines]] lines" is hella strange wording.
> Only calculate the outside lines.
Says that you need to only calculate first and last line. I know what you meant but te text doesn't say what you meant. 

And I strongly agree with Allis on this not being a good fit for the Reverse.

Hello there.
Thought that I might've been a little bit harsh in my critique. Sorry if I was.
If you need any help with that puzzle, I'll be happy to
